Program moves to reach the goal
Build a short command program to move the robot from S to G without hitting obstacles.

1) Look at the grid: S = start, G = goal, R = robot.
2) Tap Left / Forward / Right to build a program (a list of moves).
 • Left/Right rotate the robot.
 • Forward moves 1 cell in the direction the robot is facing.
3) Tap Run to execute the program step-by-step.
4) If you hit the edge of the grid, tap Reset and try again.

Solution (easy level):
Forward, Forward, Forward, Right, Forward, Forward, Forward
Legend: S = Start, G = Goal, R = Robot, # = Obstacle
Add at least one move first

Drag parts to light the LED
Drag Battery, Switch, Resistor, and LED into the slots to build a safe series circuit.

How it works:
• Long-press a part to start dragging.
• Drop it into one of the 4 slots (left → right).
• Tap the Switch slot to open/close it.
• Tap the LED slot to flip polarity (→ / ←).

Goal (solution order): Battery, Switch (closed), Resistor, LED (→)
Hint: You need a resistor and correct LED polarity.
Nice! This is a safe series circuit.

Electricity fundamentals

• Voltage (V): “electrical pressure” that pushes charge.
• Current (I): flow of charge (Amps).
• Resistance (R): how much a material/component resists current (Ohms).

Key laws & formulas
• Ohm's Law: V = I × R
• Power: P = V × I
• Energy (battery life): Wh ≈ V × Ah

Series vs parallel
• Series: same current, voltages add up across components.
• Parallel: same voltage, currents add up in branches.

Safety basics
• Always use a resistor with LEDs.
• Disconnect power before rewiring.
• Check polarity on batteries, LEDs, and electrolytic capacitors.

Circuits & electronics basics

Core components
• Resistor: limits current / sets voltage dividers.
• Capacitor: smooths noise, stores charge briefly.
• Diode/LED: allows current one way (LED also emits light).
• Transistor/MOSFET: electronic switch to control motors/LEDs.

Breadboard basics
• Middle area: connected rows for building circuits.
• Side rails: usually power (VCC) and ground (GND).

Reading diagrams
• Symbols represent parts; wires show connections.
• Ground symbols mean “same reference point.”

Arduino essentials
• Digital vs analog: digital is HIGH/LOW; analog reads a range.
• PWM is used to control brightness/motor speed.
• Always share GND between Arduino and external power sources.

Mechatronics & robotics

Actuators (motors)
• Servo motors: easy position control (angle) using pulse width.
• DC motors: continuous rotation; need a motor driver for direction + speed.

Sensors
• Ultrasonic: distance measurement (echo timing).
• IR: line following / obstacle detection (depends on sensor).
• Temperature / light: environment awareness for behavior.

Control concepts
• PWM (Pulse Width Modulation): controls average power smoothly.
• Closed-loop vs open-loop: feedback (sensors) improves accuracy.

Robot building tips
• Keep wiring tidy and secure.
• Use a stable power supply for motors (separate from logic when possible).
• Test one subsystem at a time: power → motors → sensors → communication.

Arduino basics

Pins
• Digital pins: HIGH/LOW control with digitalWrite().
• Analog inputs: read sensors with analogRead() (returns 0–1023 on many boards).
• PWM pins: analogWrite() outputs PWM for dimming LEDs / controlling motor speed (not true analog).

Core functions
• pinMode(pin, INPUT/OUTPUT/INPUT_PULLUP)
• digitalWrite(pin, HIGH/LOW)
• digitalRead(pin)
• analogRead(pin)
• analogWrite(pin, value)

Timing
• delay(ms) is simple but blocks.
• millis() lets you write non-blocking code (recommended for robots).

Interrupts (advanced)
• Useful for encoders, buttons, precise timing.
• Keep interrupt code short; avoid delay() inside interrupts.

Serial debugging
• Serial.begin(115200)
• Serial.print/println for debugging values and state
• Always confirm baud rate matches the Serial Monitor/app.

Bluetooth + WiFi

HC-05 / HC-06 (Bluetooth UART)
• Works like a serial cable over the air.
• Typical default baud: 9600 (can vary if reconfigured).
• Wiring: module TX → Arduino RX, module RX ← Arduino TX (often through a voltage divider to protect the module).

Common pairing tips
• Pair in phone settings first (PIN often 1234 or 0000).
• If connection fails: check power, wiring, and baud rate.
• Keep the module away from noisy motor wires when possible.

WiFi notes
• WiFi can have higher latency/jitter than serial.
• Use simple command packets and handle timeouts/retries in code.

Motors & drivers

Servo vs DC vs stepper
• Servo: position control (angle) using a control signal; great for joints/legs.
• DC motor: fast rotation; needs direction + speed control (robot wheels).
• Stepper: precise steps; can hold position; needs a stepper driver.

Why you need motor drivers
• Arduino pins cannot supply enough current for motors.
• Drivers protect the microcontroller and allow direction control.

Common drivers
• L298N: older, more voltage loss, gets warm.
• TB6612FNG: more efficient for small robots.

Power requirements
• Motors draw more current than logic—plan your battery/regulator accordingly.
• Always connect grounds together (common GND) between Arduino and motor supply.

Sensors

Ultrasonic (distance)
• Sends a pulse and measures echo time to estimate distance.
• Mount it firmly; avoid angled surfaces for best results.

IR line sensor / obstacle sensor
• Good for line-following and simple proximity detection.
• Needs calibration for lighting and surface color.

IMU (MPU6050 gyro/accelerometer)
• Measures rotation and acceleration.
• Often requires filtering (complementary/Kalman) to reduce noise and drift.

Calibration & noise filtering
• Take multiple readings and average (simple filter).
• Reject outliers for more stable behavior.

Power & safety

Batteries
• Li-ion/LiPo: high energy density; needs proper charging and protection.
• AA packs: simpler but bulkier; voltage drops under load.

Regulators
• Use a regulator/buck converter for stable voltage.
• Servos/motors can cause dips that reset the Arduino (brownouts).

Grounding
• Use a common ground between all modules.
• Keep motor power wiring thick/short when possible.

Brownout symptoms
• Random resets, Bluetooth disconnects, jittery servos.
• Fix by improving power delivery and adding capacitors near drivers/servos.

Robot building checklist

Wiring layout
• Route power wires away from signal wires when possible.
• Label wires or use consistent colors.

Strain relief
• Hot glue/zip ties can prevent connectors from loosening.

Debugging flow (recommended)
1) Power check: correct voltage under load
2) One motor/servo test at a time
3) Sensors: print readings to Serial
4) Communication: test simple commands first
5) Full behavior: combine systems gradually

Good habits
• Keep a “neutral pose” (like your posNeutral) for safe testing.
• Log important events over Serial/Bluetooth to diagnose issues.
